articles.headline: Trump, Angered by ‘Phony’ Inquiries, Blows Up Meeting With Pelosi and Schumer
articles.snippet: After Speaker Nancy Pelosi accused him of a “cover-up,” the president said he would not work with Democrats until they stopped investigating him.
articles.abstract: After Speaker Nancy Pelosi accused him of a “cover-up,” the president said he would not work with Democrats until they stopped investigating him.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump abruptly blew up a meeting with Democratic congressional leaders on Wednesday, declaring that he could not work with them until they stopped investigating him and lashing out at Speaker Nancy Pelosi for accusing him of a cover-up.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Katie Rogers and Emily Cochrane

articles.headline: How China Uses High-Tech Surveillance to Subdue Minorities
articles.snippet: China has turned the Xinjiang region in its far west into an incubator for automated authoritarianism that could spread across the country and beyond.
articles.abstract: China has turned the Xinjiang region in its far west into an incubator for automated authoritarianism that could spread across the country and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: KASHGAR, China — A God’s-eye view of Kashgar, an ancient city in western China, flashed onto a wall-size screen, with colorful icons marking police stations, checkpoints and the locations of recent security incidents. At the click of a mouse, a technician explained, the police can pull up live video from any surveillance camera or take a closer look at anyone passing through one of the thousands of checkpoints in the city.
articles.byline: By Chris Buckley and Paul Mozur

articles.headline: Harriet Tubman $20 Bill Is Delayed Until Trump Leaves Office, Mnuchin Says
articles.snippet: President Trump said in 2016 that the Obama-era decision to put Tubman on the bill was “pure political correctness.’’ Now it won’t be in circulation until 2028.
articles.abstract: President Trump said in 2016 that the Obama-era decision to put Tubman on the bill was “pure political correctness.’’ Now it won’t be in circulation until 2028.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Harriet Tubman — former slave, abolitionist, “conductor” on the Underground Railroad — will not become the face of the $20 bill until after President Trump leaves office, Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said Wednesday.

articles.headline: Trump’s Financial Secrets Move Closer to Disclosure
articles.snippet: A federal judge rejected President Trump’s efforts to block banks from complying with congressional subpoenas, and New York lawmakers voted to let Congress obtain his state tax returns.
articles.abstract: A federal judge rejected President Trump’s efforts to block banks from complying with congressional subpoenas, and New York lawmakers voted to let Congress obtain his state tax returns.
articles.lead_paragraph: For three years, Donald J. Trump has treated the details of his personal and business finances as a closely guarded secret.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter, Jesse McKinley, David Enrich and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: ‘Fetal Heartbeat’ vs. ‘Forced Pregnancy’: The Language Wars of the Abortion Debate
articles.snippet: Activists on both sides of the abortion fight have long chosen their words carefully, coining terms like “pro-life,” “pro-choice” and “partial-birth abortion.”
articles.abstract: Activists on both sides of the abortion fight have long chosen their words carefully, coining terms like “pro-life,” “pro-choice” and “partial-birth abortion.”
articles.lead_paragraph: The new laws that prohibit abortion as early as the sixth week of pregnancy have been called “heartbeat” legislation by supporters, a reference to the flickering pulse that can be seen on ultrasound images of a developing embryo.

articles.headline: What Reparations for Slavery Might Look Like in 2019
articles.snippet: The idea of economic amends for past injustices and persistent disparities is getting renewed attention. Here are some formulas for achieving the aim.
articles.abstract: The idea of economic amends for past injustices and persistent disparities is getting renewed attention. Here are some formulas for achieving the aim.
articles.lead_paragraph: If you’re surprised that the issue of reparations for black Americans has taken so long to resolve, blame the president. President Andrew Johnson.

articles.headline: Trump Gives Farmers $16 Billion in Aid Amid Prolonged China Trade War
articles.snippet: The Trump administration announced an aid package for farmers on Thursday to mollify an important political constituency hurt by a trade clash with China.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration announced an aid package for farmers on Thursday to mollify an important political constituency hurt by a trade clash with China.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Thursday unveiled a $16 billion bailout for farmers hurt by his trade war with Beijing, signaling a protracted fight ahead that is already prompting some American companies to shift business away from China.

articles.headline: Narendra Modi, India’s ‘Watchman,’ Captures Historic Election Victory
articles.snippet: Mr. Modi’s party captured a commanding parliamentary majority for the second time in a row, a feat not achieved for decades.
articles.abstract: Mr. Modi’s party captured a commanding parliamentary majority for the second time in a row, a feat not achieved for decades.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — He called himself India’s watchman, even as minorities said they felt unsafe under his gaze. He boasted of his humble origins while doing favors for billionaires. He spoke the language of business, yet could not deliver enough jobs to Indians aspiring to a better life.
articles.byline: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Vindu Goel, Kai Schultz, Suhasini Raj and Hari Kumar

articles.headline: China’s Supply of Minerals for iPhones and Missiles Could Be a Risky Trade Weapon
articles.snippet: The country dominates production of the rare earths used in myriad technologies, but tangled global supply chains make it hard to hit the U.S. directly.
articles.abstract: The country dominates production of the rare earths used in myriad technologies, but tangled global supply chains make it hard to hit the U.S. directly.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — President Xi Jinping of China strode this week through a high-ceilinged factory that makes magnets out of rare earths, minerals that are essential to global manufacturing and a sector that his country dominates. His top trade negotiator, Vice Premier Liu He, stood near.
